keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices in many cases, raising serious concerns about identity theft and fraud.
The Italian businessman scam, involving fake calls from Defence Minister Guido Crosetto, demonstrates how AI voice cloning can be used to manipulate individuals into transferring money.

Research by Queen Mary University of London found that 41% of AI-generated voices and 58% of voice clones were mistaken for real human voices, with participants often rating AI voices as more trustworthy.
AI deepfakes are being used to create fake news, impersonate individuals, and generate illegal sexual content, including child sexual abuse material.
Global policy responses, such as US legislation banning AI-generated intimate images and Australia banning a specific app used to create deepfake nudes, reflect growing concern about AI misuse.
Despite risks, AI-generated voices offer beneficial applications, such as restoring speech for individuals with speech impairments.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing wave of AI-powered voice scams has targeted prominent Italian businessmen, including Giorgio Armani and Patrizio Bertelli, with fraudsters using deepfake technology to mimic the voice of Defence Minister Guido Crosetto and request large financial transfers. The scam, which occurred in February 2025, was only uncovered when Crosetto himself received a suspicious call and reported it to the police. Research from Queen Mary University of London shows that AI-generated voice clones are now indistinguishable from real human voices, with participants rating them as more trustworthy. Global losses from such deepfakes have surged to over $547 million between January and June 2025, and AI-generated content, including child sexual abuse material, has become a major global concern. In response, the United States and Australia have introduced legislative measures to criminalize the publication of AI-generated intimate images, while technology companies like Resemble AI and DeepMedia are monitoring and attempting to detect synthetic media. Despite the risks, AI voice technology also offers valuable applications, such as helping individuals who have lost their ability to speak.
